author: By Edward Wong
title: Blinken Urges Rwanda and Congo to End Support for Warring Militias
description: Antony J. Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, said he had warned the leaders of both nations over violence in the east of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
content: KIGALI, Rwanda — Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Thursday that he had urged the leaders of Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo to end their support for militias in eastern Congo, warning that continuing to back the groups threatened stability across the Great Lakes region of Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Lamp That’s Taking Over New York
description: A sleek newcomer, the Pina Pro, is appearing on droves of outdoor tables in the city — and sometimes disappearing, as diners fall for its mellow glow.
content: She’s tall and svelte, with a sleek conical hat. She frequents New York City’s most coveted restaurant tables. She lights up a room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: The Padres Got a Sword. But Can They Slay the ‘Dragon’?
description: Juan Soto headlined San Diego’s audacious haul at the trading deadline. Keeping up with the Los Angeles Dodgers, in spending and on the field, won’t be easy.
content: SAN DIEGO — Juan Soto had barely landed, Josh Bell had just sat down and Josh Hader was starting to learn his new teammates’ names when Peter Seidler, the Padres’ owner, declared that “the art of the possible is here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanif  Abdurraqib
title: The Art of Disappearance
description: Some might hear the music of Connie Converse, who drove off without a trace in 1974, as a haunting record of depression. But what about the liberation?
content: The problem — or at least a problem, I’ve been told — is that I am not very concerned about being missed upon any of my exits, not the ones that are voluntary nor the ones that swoop down without warning to cover me in a quilt of dark feathers. I think about this often, and if there is a remedy for it. I read the sometimes long, sprawling announcements people make when they leave or take breaks from social media platforms, or I watch someone announce that he or she is departing on the way out of a crowded party, and I sometimes find myself puzzled by the practice. I slip out of parties unannounced. I make up excuses for why I didn’t make the rounds, or say goodbye. I see the concerned texts, I tell myself I’ll reply later and sometimes I do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Eileen Sullivan
title: Draft Shows Watchdog Took Months to Report Missing Secret Service Texts
description: The disclosure of the draft notification to Congress is the latest evidence to raise questions about the inspector general’s handling of the missing Jan. 6 texts.
content: WASHINGTON — The Department of Homeland Security’s internal watchdog took months to alert Congress to missing Secret Service text messages around the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol even after lawyers had approved a draft notification, leaving the information out of a key report and eventually releasing only a milder version, newly released documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: The Tricky Math of Retiring Into a Downturn
description: Market declines during the first five years of retirement can have a significant effect on a financial portfolio, but remaining flexible can mitigate the damage.
content: Most Americans finance their retirement with a certain amount of faith: Investing will help their savings keep pace with inflation, institutions will continue to work as they always have, it will all work out in the end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The most informative — and sensitive — document connected to the search of Mar-a-Lago will not be made public for now.
description: The affidavit in support of the warrant explains why prosecutors believed there was probable cause that evidence of a crime could found be at the Florida estate.
content: As remarkable as it was for the Justice Department to ask a federal judge on Thursday to unseal the warrant it used this week to search Mar-a-Lago, former President Donald J. Trump’s private residence in Florida, the materials that prosecutors have agreed to make public are not the most informative or sensitive connected to the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: At Edinburgh’s Festivals, Big Names and Live Issues
description: While marquee productions have featured star turns from Ian McKellen and Alan Cumming, smaller shows deal with contemporary life.
content: EDINBURGH — Some big names have been leaving their mark this month in Edinburgh, where both the International Festival and the bustling theatrical grab bag that is the Fringe are in full swing after a slimmed-down pandemic lineup last year. Ian McKellen and Alan Cumming have proved box-office catnip, both of them in dance-intensive enterprises that take already long-established careers in new directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim
title: For Palestinian Prisoners, Hunger Strikes Are a Battle of Stomachs
description: For decades, Palestinians imprisoned by Israel have used these protests as a way to demand better living conditions and an end to indefinite detentions.
content: DURA, West Bank — In the Israeli prison where Kayed al-Fasfos spent nine months without charge or trial, a handwritten book hidden from the guards offered some guidance on a possible way out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Farago
title: How the war changed a Kyiv museum’s view of its past.
description: KYIV, Ukraine — Most of the galleries are now empty at the Mystetskyi Arsenal, one of Europe’s largest art museums. As at almost every cultural institution in the Ukrainian capital, its curators and archivists brought down the displays when war broke out on Feb. 24. Much of the collection of about 4,500 objects has been moved to a secure location. Gallery after gallery sits in darkness. And yet: this summer, the Mystetskyi Arsenal is open to the public, with a forceful and beautiful exhibition that’s all the more impressive for its modesty and frank emotions.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Most of the galleries are now empty at the Mystetskyi Arsenal, one of Europe’s largest art museums. As at almost every cultural institution in the Ukrainian capital, its curators and archivists brought down the displays when war broke out on Feb. 24. Much of the collection of about 4,500 objects has been moved to a secure location. Gallery after gallery sits in darkness. And yet: this summer, the Mystetskyi Arsenal is open to the public, with a forceful and beautiful exhibition that’s all the more impressive for its modesty and frank emotions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Inu-oh’ Review: Dazzling Anime Meets Medieval Epic
description: This modern riff on “The Tale of the Heike,” from 14th-century Japan, takes some confusing turns. But the animation is undeniably wonderful.
content: Visually sumptuous and narratively tangled, the anime “Inu-oh” takes place in 14th-century Japan. The main story does, at least. It tells of two young, audaciously talented castaways — a blind musician and a cursed dancer — who meet one dark evening. After the usual how-do-you-do, they begin performing for each other and quickly slide into enchanted sync. Together, they frolic and jam and whirl, and before long they’re levitating, gyrating against an expanse of shimmery stars as they orbit each other like heavenly bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Ben Protess and Glenn Thrush
title: Trump received a subpoena from the Justice Department ahead of the F.B.I.’s Mar-a-Lago search.
description: Former President Donald J. Trump received a subpoena this spring in search of documents that federal investigators believed he had failed to turn over earlier in the year, when he returned boxes of material he had improperly taken with him upon moving out of the White House, three people familiar with the matter said.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump received a subpoena this spring in search of documents that federal investigators believed he had failed to turn over earlier in the year, when he returned boxes of material he had improperly taken with him upon moving out of the White House, three people familiar with the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña and Christiaan Triebert
title: Zelensky addresses the explosions in Crimea as photos suggest a major loss for Russia.
description: With satellite images showing at least eight wrecked warplanes after explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said late Wednesday that Moscow’s mounting losses should persuade its leadership to “find a way out of the war.”
content: With satellite images showing at least eight wrecked warplanes after explosions at a Russian air base in Crimea, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said late Wednesday that Moscow’s mounting losses should persuade its leadership to “find a way out of the war.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Simon
title: Marriage, With a Side of Pickleball
description: As pickleball rides a wave of popularity, couples are marrying on courts, hosting games at their receptions and finding other ways to incorporate the sport into their nuptials.
content: Julene and Charles Wood had played pickleball as a couple several times at the Evergreen Racquet Club in Bloomington, Ill., after first meeting on a court there in March 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samira Sawlani
title: Young Kenyans Are Being Asked to Crown Their New Oppressor, and the Answer Is No
description: Presented with two stalwarts of the status quo, many are opting out.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — It was a sight to behold. Scores of young people, excited and expectant, gathered in Nairobi, chanting slogans and waving banners. But it was no entertainment: They were there for a campaign rally. In the months leading up to Kenya’s elections on Tuesday, the scene was repeated across the country. Here, it seemed, were the future custodians of the country taking a lively interest in the political process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Friday Briefing: U.S. to Unseal Trump Warrant
description: Plus Russia prepares for show trials and Taiwan does not rise to China’s provocations.
content: Merrick Garland, the U.S. attorney general, moved to unseal the warrant authorizing the F.B.I. search for classified documents at Mar-a-Lago, Donald Trump’s residence in Florida. Garland said he personally approved the decision to seek the warrant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Yuhas and Shashank Bengali
title: Shelling Threatens Ukrainian Nuclear Plant, and U.N. Pleads for Access
description: The chief U.N. nuclear monitor called for an immediate stop to fighting that risks a radiation disaster, as Russians and Ukrainians blamed each other for strikes dangerously close to the reactors.
content: Shelling in Ukraine once again threatened the largest nuclear power plant in Europe on Thursday, damaging equipment on the grounds, as Russian and Ukrainian forces blamed each other for creating the risk of a catastrophic nuclear accident in the middle of a war zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constance Paige Young
title: I Was Injured by a White Supremacist in Charlottesville. Strangers Lifted Me Up.
description: Since the attack in Charlottesville, I’ve relied heavily on my community in my journey toward healing.
content: In July 2017 a friend told me that white supremacists planned to go to Charlottesville, Va., to protest the removal of a statue of Robert E. Lee from a city park that August. I immediately knew I would go to counterprotest and provide support for others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: This weeks properties are in Park Slope, Turtle Bay and on the Upper West Side.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Girl Picture’ Review: Teens on Thin Ice
description: This Finnish comedy about three high school girls grants them a judgment-free sanctuary.
content: “Girl Picture,” directed by Alli Haapasalo, is a giddy, high-strung comedy about three Finnish high schoolers anxious to capitalize on that sliver of teenagedom when life is all possibilities — a period that races by so fast that the film, written by Ilona Ahti and Daniela Hakulinen, is able to cram a smorgasbord of joy and humiliation into just three weekends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jody Freeman
title: The Climate Bill Isn’t Perfect, but It’s Still a Major Victory
description: There may be better ways to slow global warming, but this legislation is a big step forward.
content: In an ideal world, the climate provisions now making their way through Congress as part of the Inflation Reduction Act would directly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and discourage the use of fossil fuels.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Renaissance in American Hardcore Music
description: A look at the recent burst of bands and how the scene operates as music, ethic and feeling.
content: American hardcore music is experiencing a creative burst at the moment, owing to bands including Gulch, Scowl, Drug Church, Drain, Mindforce and End It. The scene has its own network of YouTube channels, podcasts and websites that catalog it. And last month’s Sound and Fury Festival in Los Angeles was a powerful statement of purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 11, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 11, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about the search at former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida described incorrectly how the National Archives retrieved 15 boxes of material that Mr. Trump had improperly taken with him when he left the White House. The agency said it arranged to have the boxes picked up from Mr. Trump’s home at Mar-a-Lago. It did not fly an official to Florida to collect them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Liz Cheney embraces her role in the Jan. 6 inquiry in a closing campaign ad.
description: The nearly two-and-a-half-minute ad appeared aimed as much at a national audience as at voters in Wyoming, where she is badly trailing her primary opponent.
content: Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming is highlighting her role as the top Republican on the Jan. 6 committee in a closing ad for her all but doomed re-election campaign, as polls show her badly trailing her Trump-backed opponent, Harriet Hageman, just five days before the primary.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Beth Macy’s Parents Never Bought Books. They Borrowed Them.
description: “My late mother refused to even buy my books because why buy them when you can get them free at the library?” says the journalist and author, whose latest book is “Raising Lazarus.” “I gave her copies, of course.”
content: I just finished Geraldine Brooks’s “Horse” — set in contemporary times as well as the antebellum era and during the Civil War, but every story line is so pertinent to the issues of the day. On deck I have a galley of Rachel Louise Snyder’s forthcoming memoir, “Women We Buried, Women We Burned,” which promises to be as poignant, propulsive and important as her previous book, “No Visible Bruises.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kalia Richardson
title: ‘Bodies Bodies Bodies’ and the Difficulty of Coping IRL
description: What happens when Gen Z loses Wi-Fi? Using horror and humor, the cast and filmmakers of the new slasher film aim for a generational portrait.
content: A lip-locking close-up is the first we see of Sophie (played by Amandla Stenberg) and Bee, her girlfriend of six weeks (Maria Bakalova). Seemingly pulled from the pages of a fairy tale, Sophie confesses her love for Bee as they lie in a green meadow surrounded by nature. Within seconds, that affectionate scene gives way to a shot of the two absorbed in their phones as agitating dings and notifications dry up any remnants of intimacy or passion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: 110° at Showtime: Venues Are Grappling With Climate Change
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 11, 2022.
content: “Once it’s 110 degrees at 6 o’clock at night, and we have these occasionally already, people are sick. You can’t do the big Shakespeare fight, you can’t do the dances in ‘Mamma Mia.’ And you can’t do that to an audience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Season for Grated Tomatoes
description: Plus a bonus recipe for sizzled eggplant.
content: I showed up at a friend’s place over the weekend with a pint of Sungold tomatoes and a handful of purple Chinese eggplants, knowing we’d turn it into something delicious for dinner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serena Solomon
title: How New Zealand’s Climate Fight Is Threatening Its Iconic Farmland
description: As the country puts a growing price on greenhouse emissions, investors are rushing to buy up pastures and plant carbon-sucking trees.
content: GISBORNE, New Zealand — Horehore Station, a sheep and cattle ranch, sprawls across 4,000 acres on New Zealand’s North Island, its jagged expanse of uneven hills and steep gullies blanketed in lush green grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: Daniel Silva Would Like You to Be Quiet
description: The former journalist, author of 25 spy thrillers and a stalwart on the best-seller list, opens up about his writerly quirks.
content: Daniel Silva begins a phone interview with an apology for taking a few hours to respond to a request for a phone interview.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Erdogan and Putin: Complicated Relations With Mutual Benefits
description: Turkey needs Russian cash, gas and business as Erdogan looks to a dicey election and a new incursion in Syria, while Moscow needs friends to try to evade Western sanctions.
content: BRUSSELS — Turkey’s mercurial president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is in political difficulty before elections next year, with his economy imploding, a central bank nearly out of foreign exchange and volcanic inflation running at about 80 percent annually.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: ‘Secret Headquarters’ Review: You Know, for Kids
description: A group of plucky tweens get in on some superhero action in this kid-friendly action comedy.
content: “Secret Headquarters,” from the directors Henry Joost and Ariel Schulman, is in essence a superhero movie designed for children — a lighthearted, low-stakes action blockbuster in which a coterie of plucky tweens must defend the earth by wielding an array of otherworldly powers. The story is very similar to “Spy Kids” (2001), Robert Rodriguez’s whimsical espionage thriller about preteen siblings who discover that their parents are world-class secret agents. In this film, a boy named Charlie (Walker Scobell, “The Adam Project”) deduces that his absent father (Owen Wilson) has been living a double life as the Iron Man-like hero named the Guard. Charlie discovers this after he and his friends stumble upon an underground lair beneath his home; as in “Spy Kids,” the veteran parent soon finds need for junior backup, which the intrepid little kids are all too eager to provide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: ‘Five Days at Memorial’ Tells the Harrowing Story of a Deadly Choice
description: A new scripted series on Apple TV+ dramatizes the crisis faced by a New Orleans hospital after Hurricane Katrina, as the waters and the death toll rose.
content: It was tense and sweaty on the set of “Five Days at Memorial,” the new Apple TV+ limited series about systemic and personal failure at a New Orleans hospital in the days after Hurricane Katrina. The cast, emotionally invested and physically drained, was wiped out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oliver Whang
title: All Hooting Aside: Did a Vocal Evolution Give Rise to Language?
description: The loss of certain muscles in the human larynx may have helped give our species a voice, a new study suggests.
content: Read this sentence aloud, if you’re able.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Simonetti
title: Gas Prices in the U.S. Fall Below $4 a Gallon
description: After peaking in June, they are back where they were in March, offering some relief to consumers and policymakers amid inflation worries.
content: Gas prices in the United States fell below $4 a gallon on Thursday, retreating to their lowest level since March, a sign of relief for Americans struggling with historically high inflation and a political boost for President Biden, who has been under pressure to do more to bring down prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Free Chol Soo Lee’ Review: An Indictment of the Justice System
description: Activists helped free a Korean immigrant, and this documentary explores the wrongful conviction and its ripple effect.
content: “Free Chol Soo Lee” tells the story of a wrongfully convicted man who, after spending nearly a decade in prison, was ultimately vindicated in court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Princess’ Review: An Unsparing Look at Princess Diana
description: The director Ed Perkins uses only found footage to create a harrowing account of Diana’s life and death.
content: The first clue that “The Princess” will not be your standard-issue Diana Spencer documentary is that the director is Ed Perkins. Perkins’s last film, “Tell Me Who I Am” (2019), which was also his first feature, told a painful true story of identical twins whose lives were upended by abuse and memory loss. While its perspective was compassionate, its revelations were presented in a way that could best be called unsparing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: On TikTok, Knitting, Rapping and Promoting the Child Tax Credit
description: In an experiment with influencers, two young progressive strategists tapped apolitical accounts to promote policy-related content, focusing on reaching young voters of color.
content: What do a rapper, a parody specialist and a knitting-obsessed makeup artist have in common?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Trump, at New Jersey Fund-Raiser, is Buoyed by Supporters
description: The former president spoke at a gathering for Representative Jeff Van Drew hours after invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination at his deposition in Manhattan.
content: Hours after his deposition Wednesday in Manhattan, former President Donald J. Trump returned to his golf club in Bedminster, N.J., to host a fund-raiser for Representative Jeff Van Drew, a onetime Democrat who joined the Republican Party in 2019 after pledging his “undying support” to Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Fall’ Review: Things Are Looking Down
description: In this nerve-shredding thriller, two young women fight to survive while stranded on top of a 2,000-foot TV tower.
content: If you, too, are afraid of heights, you’re likely to experience “Fall” as a straightforward horror movie instead of a thriller. The director Scott Mann has certainly packed this latest venture with enough jump scares and bloodshed to blur genre lines. As a result, “Fall” occasionally feels overrun with gimmicks and gotchas, but it also offers one hell of an adrenaline rush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Tiny Oysters Are a Hopeful Sign in the Hudson River
description: The River Project is trying to bring back oysters, which thrived in the Hudson at a time when New York was known as “the Big Oyster.”
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Strap on a life jacket as we ride out into the Hudson River with marine biologists who are checking on oysters in the Hudson’s continuing comeback. We’ll also see what’s next in the New York attorney general’s case against Donald Trump in the wake of Trump’s decision to cite the Fifth Amendment’s protection against self-incrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Stay on Board: The Leo Baker Story’ Review: Surviving the Grind
description: In this documentary, a professional skateboarder turns down the Olympics for the chance to live openly.
content: When Leo Baker began skateboarding professionally in the early 2000s, skateboarding was mainly a hobby for punks. There were no Olympic trials for national teams, and advertisers were only beginning to notice the profits that could come from marketing sneakers and T-shirts to kids doing kick flips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yana Dlugy
title: Safety Fears at Nuclear Plant
description: International concern is growing after days of shelling around Zaporizhzhia station.
content: Hello. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu and Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Johnson & Johnson Will Discontinue Talc-Based Baby Powder Globally in 2023
description: The company, sued by cancer patients who claimed its talc was contaminated with asbestos, stopped using the ingredient in North America in 2020.
content: Johnson & Johnson will start using cornstarch in all the baby powder it sells around the world, shifting away from the talcum powder that put the popular product at the center of tens of thousands of lawsuits filed by customers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Italy Salutes a War Hero and the Values He Fought For
description: Mario Fiorentini, Italy’s most decorated resistance fighter, died at age 103 this week, and his mourners want his legacy to live on.
content: ROME — Many of the mourners at the wake and funeral of Mario Fiorentini — Italy’s most decorated resistance fighter, who died on Tuesday at age 103 — had stories to tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Bradley
title: The Artists Taking on Mass Incarceration
description: More and more art is challenging long-held assumptions about the criminal justice system.
content: WHEN THE INTERDISCIPLINARY artist Maria Gaspar was 12 years old, her teachers took her to jail. It was the early 1990s, in the era of Scared Straight programs aimed at curbing juvenile delinquency, and Gaspar and her classmates were deemed “at risk,” by virtue of where they lived — the West Side of Chicago — and who they were, many of them first-generation immigrants from Mexico. Back then, on any given day, Cook County Jail, located in the city’s South Lawndale neighborhood, housed some 8,000 people, a third of them pretrial detainees unable to post bail, mostly men, Black and brown. Gaspar remembers her frightened teachers, all of them white, scurrying through tiered cellblocks; the inedible food served to them in the mess hall; the guards scolding the young visitors for crossing their legs and for “not being ‘clean.’” But her clearest memory is of the faces of those who gazed back at her from their confinement. “I remember feeling like the guys behind bars looked like people down my block,” she says. “They just looked like people I knew. That stuck with me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Free Puppies!’ Review: A Fight to Save a Dog’s Life
description: This documentary focuses on volunteer animal rescue groups in the rural United States.
content: Animal lovers will find a bittersweet watch in “Free Puppies!,” a documentary on volunteer rescue groups working to adopt dogs in areas of the United States that are high in strays and, subsequently, high in euthanasia rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams
title: The gunman is hiding in farmland after a chase with the police.
description: A man who witnessed the pursuit said the police “have him contained” near a family farm.
content: WILMINGTON, Ohio — When Rob Thompson left to run errands shortly after 10 a.m., he was greeted at the end of his driveway by a speeding white Crown Victoria being pursued by several police officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘Laal Singh Chaddha’ Review: Forrest Gump in India
description: This Indian adaptation of “Forrest Gump” doubles down on its Pollyanna hero, substituting different historical touchstones.
content: “Forrest Gump” has been called many things: a feel-good crowd-pleaser, a maddening piece of pap, and America’s version of Voltaire’s “Candide” (per the film scholar Dave Kehr). “Laal Singh Chaddha” offers up a fresh look: a luxuriantly produced Indian adaptation that doubles down on the story’s simpleton hero, with new historical touchstones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Too Darn Hot: How Summer Stages Are Threatened by Climate Change
description: In the West, wildfires are stopping shows. Extreme heat has led to cancellations in the South. And changing weather patterns are hobbling performances in the Northeast.
content: ASHLAND, Ore. — Smoke from a raging wildfire in California prompted the Oregon Shakespeare Festival to cancel a recent performance of “The Tempest” at its open-air theater. Record flooding in St. Louis forced the cancellation of an outdoor performance of “Legally Blonde.” And after heat and smoke at an outdoor Pearl Jam concert in France damaged the throat of its lead singer, Eddie Vedder, the band canceled several shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Too Darn Hot: How Summer Stages Are Threatened by Climate Change
description: In the West, wildfires are stopping shows. Extreme heat has led to cancellations in the South. And changing weather patterns are hobbling performances in the Northeast.
content: ASHLAND, Ore. — Smoke from a raging wildfire in California prompted the Oregon Shakespeare Festival to cancel a recent performance of “The Tempest” at its open-air theater. Record flooding in St. Louis forced the cancellation of an outdoor performance of “Legally Blonde.” And after heat and smoke at an outdoor Pearl Jam concert in France damaged the throat of its lead singer, Eddie Vedder, the band canceled several shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Absurd Argument Against Making Trump Obey the Law
description: Don’t give the former president’s fans an insurrectionist veto.
content: This article has been updated to include new information about a man who attempted to breach an F.B.I. field office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Jean-Jacques Sempé, Cartoonist of Droll Whimsy, Dies at 89
description: Beloved in France and popular around the world, he drew more than 100 covers for The New Yorker in an association that began in 1978.
content: Jean-Jacques Sempé, the French cartoonist known in America for children’s book illustrations and for covers for The New Yorker portraying tiny, gentle people with big noses at poignant moments, often dwarfed by monumental backgrounds, died on Thursday. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Damage from a blast in Crimea.
content: Satellite photos taken after a series of explosions on Tuesday at a Russian air base in Crimea appear to show at least three blast craters and at least eight wrecked warplanes, indicating a serious blow to the Russian military contradicting the Kremlin’s account. Russian authorities had previously denied that any aircraft had been destroyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Emily the Criminal’ Review: Survival Strategy
description: Aubrey Plaza’s wonderfully nuanced performance anchors this absorbing story of a young woman’s descent into lawlessness.
content: “Want to make $200 in an hour?” reads the anonymous text, and Emily (Aubrey Plaza) absolutely does. On her own, in her thirties and out of options, Emily is struggling to repay $70,000 in student loans by working a punishing food-delivery job with no protections or a reliable schedule. A talented artist, she longs to land a graphic-design position like her best friend, Liz (Megalyn Echikunwoke), but an old assault conviction makes for awkward interviews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruben Quesada and Victoria Chang
title: Poem: Oath Keeper
description: The only thing that’s certain in this short work is the uncontainable passion it depicts.
content: Ruben Quesada’s short poem reminds me of Edward Hopper’s paintings in their austere and mysterious scenes, leaving the viewer curious about the people in the paintings and the unspoken secrets of their lives. Even in the first few lines, the visible presses against the hidden: “coppiced topped tree-lined/sidewalks” versus the dark of the “tunnels/and alleys.” The jarring shift to “After hours on my knees” follows quickly after natural scenery. The language is secret, too: “A voice” is unspecified, as is the “fury of men,” who are instead likened to animals. Even the room is rented and impersonal. The only thing that is certain is the uncontainable passion, as depicted by the final two lines. Poem Selected by Victoria Chang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Sylvan Esso’s New Album of Electro-pop Challenges All Expectations
description: The duo’s fourth LP, “No Rules Sandy,” revels in constantly shifting sounds that are “surreal but free.”
content: The electronic vertigo revs up immediately and rarely lets up on “No Rules Sandy,” the fourth studio album by Sylvan Esso. “How can I be moved when everything is moving,” Amelia Meath calmly muses in the opening track, “Moving,” over a hissing, scurrying beat, octave-swooping blips and stereo-panning whooshes that keep things spinning. It’s a whirlwind start to an album that celebrates renewed, unconstrained motion: lighthearted on the surface, purposeful at its core.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: This week’s recommended titles include starkly different accounts of complicated parent-daughter relationships, from Lynne Tillman’s cleareyed description of caring for a remote and often critical mother in declining health to Mary Rodgers’s rollicking memoir of life as Broadway royalty, growing up with parents who were likewise remote and critical: the composer Richard Rodgers and (especially) the writer and entrepreneur Dorothy Rodgers, who was such a piece of work that one chapter of this book is titled “I Dismember Mama.” On the fiction side, Mecca Jamilah Sullivan’s debut novel follows an overweight 8-year-old girl whose parents bring their own body issues to raising her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: In the Mile High City, Festivals and Food Are on the Rise
description: Denver has regained its prepandemic vibrancy, with a plethora of new restaurants and hotels, and the return of some old favorites.
content: On a recent Tuesday evening, diners surrounded marble-topped bistro tables at Chez Maggy in the new Thompson hotel, open since February in Denver’s LoDo neighborhood. The draw: the opportunity to taste the chef Ludo Lefebvre’s classic French fare — garlicky escargot, curry-tinged mussels frites, duck breast à l’orange — at his first venture outside of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: C.D.C. Eases Covid Guidelines, Noting Virus Is ‘Here to Stay’
description: The new guidelines eliminate quarantines and put less emphasis on social distancing, routine surveillance testing and contact tracing.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention loosened Covid-19 guidelines on Thursday, freeing schools and businesses from the onus of requiring unvaccinated people exposed to the virus to quarantine at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jillian Steinhauer
title: A Bigger Canvas for Jayson Musson Includes Puppets and Picasso
description: He’s back to making videos that poke fun at the ways of the art world, but a sprawling new show allows viewers to see how he puts it all together.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The film set on view at the Fabric Workshop and Museum looks like a museum gift shop gone wildly awry. A copy of Michelangelo’s “Pietà” has been turned into a chair by removing most of Jesus’s body to make space for a cushion. A nude figure from Picasso’s “Les Demoiselles d’Avignon” (1907) has been rendered in three dimensions as a coat rack. The anamorphic skull image in Hans Holbein’s “The Ambassadors” (1533) forms the surface of a coffee table. And amid it all sits a large animatronic puppet: a scruffy, gray pothead rabbit named Ollie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Marcus
title: The Independent Bookstore, as Imagined by a Corporate Lobbyist
description: Bradley Tusk, a Bloomberg and Uber fixer who has opened a new bookstore in downtown Manhattan, thinks running that kind of business can be seen as philanthropy.
content: Sitting at the bar in the exclusive Delta Club at Citi Field, where his beloved Mets were in the process of sweeping the Yankees in the Subway Series, the political fixer and venture capitalist Bradley Tusk described his designs on the future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Naroditsky
title: Chess Replay: You Versus Gurgenidze
description: Take on Bukhuti Gurgenidze in a recreation of a 24th U.S.S.R. Championship game in Moscow, 1957. Solve for the best series of moves.
content: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: The Cookie Jar Grows Up
description: Looking to escape distractions? Lock them away in a box.
content: Humans have a natural talent for concentration. I recently watched a kid crouching among pebbles at the beach. He spent eons sorting among sea-worn ovoids — not vapidly, but with an air of zealous exploration. Finally, he found what he sought: the perfect pebble. (What made it perfect? I don’t know. Doesn’t matter.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: Our TV critic recommends checking out a new comedy, a juicy finale and a returning teen rom-com.
content: ‘This Fool’When to watch: Arrives Friday, on Hulu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Activist Investor ValueAct Takes Stake in The New York Times
description: The investor, which has taken positions in Adobe, Citigroup and Nintendo, is pushing The Times to sell bundled subscriptions to readers more aggressively.
content: ValueAct, an activist investor that has taken stakes in major companies including Microsoft, Reuters and 21st Century Fox, said on Thursday that it had bought nearly 7 percent of The New York Times Company’s common stock and would push for changes to some of the publisher’s business operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Gryvatz Copquin and Lisa Prevost
title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: This week’s properties are a seven-bedroom in Roslyn, N.Y., and a five-bedroom in Stamford, Conn.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: The New ‘Monuments Officers’ Prepare to Protect Art Amid War
description: A group of art experts have had intensive training to become part of the U.S. Army Reserve. It will be their job to help save cultural heritage in war zones.
content: FORT BELVOIR, Va. — The Army Reserve officers worked with brisk efficiency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: What to Do With an Absent Father? Cast Him as a Character Onstage.
description: The experimental theater maker Aya Ogawa ponders her distant father as well as failure and forgiveness in “The Nosebleed” at Lincoln Center Theater.
content: The Brooklyn-based experimental theater maker Aya Ogawa hadn’t thought about her father in 10 years. When that fact occurred to her, in 2017 — a decade after his death, which she and her mother had chosen not to mark with a funeral, or even an obituary in the local newspaper in his California town — she didn’t feel guilty about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: The Golden Arches Return to Ukraine After a 6-Month Hiatus
description: McDonald’s said it would begin reopening stores in Kyiv and western Ukraine as fighting continues in the east.
content: McDonald’s will begin reopening its restaurants in Kyiv and western Ukraine, the company said Thursday, in response to what it called the “strong desire” of many employees to return to their jobs despite the war with Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: How to View the Last Supermoon of the Year
description: The Sturgeon Moon will be visible in the night sky Thursday.
content: Stargazers, take note: The full moon on Thursday night will be slightly larger and more vibrant than usual. It’s also the last supermoon of the year, according to NASA.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ankush Khardori
title: The American People Deserve to Know What the Justice Department Is Up To
description: After the Mar-a-Lago search, the department should be doing more to counter the condemnation from the right and address questions from the public.
content: In the days since the F.B.I. searched Donald Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence, this country has been consumed by a predictable form of asymmetric political and media warfare. The former president and his conservative supporters have loudly condemned the tactics and supposed political bias of prosecutors, while the investigators have remained silent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Mazzetti
title: The Poisoned Relationship Between Trump and the Keepers of U.S. Secrets
description: The F.B.I. search of Mar-a-Lago is a coda to the years of tumult between an erratic president and the nation’s intelligence and law enforcement agencies.
content: WASHINGTON— After four years of President Donald J. Trump’s raging against his intelligence services, posting classified information to Twitter and announcing that he took the word of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia over that of his own spies, perhaps the least surprising thing he did during his final days in office was ship boxes of sensitive material from the White House to his oceanside palace in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Williams, Alan Feuer, Adam Goldman and Mitch Smith
title: Man Accused of Trying to Break Into F.B.I. Office Is Killed in Standoff
description: Two law enforcement officials said investigators were looking into whether the man had ties to extremist groups, including one that participated in the Jan. 6 attack.
content: WILMINGTON, Ohio — After an hourslong standoff that closed an interstate and disrupted rural life, law enforcement officers shot and killed a man who they said tried to break into the F.B.I.’s Cincinnati office on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Hass
title: A Glossy Rainbow Fireplace From Luca Guadagnino
description: The filmmaker’s pastel hearth, the latest release from his design studio, is another chapter in his longstanding fascination with interiors.
content: There’s an elegant logic to the fact that Luca Guadagnino, the 51-year-old Italian director of films such as “Call Me by Your Name,” runs a design studio. After all, his movies are as much about atmosphere as they are character; to him, objects are also metaphors, whether a marble corridor that stands in for bourgeois restraint or a peach that represents the opposite. His most recent creation, a fireplace, was inspired by its function as the spiritual center of the home. Forgoing traditional materials such as stone and brick, he had Munich’s famed Nymphenburg Porcelain Manufactory fabricate this vivid pastel-hued ceramic hearth, which can be made in different sizes and palettes (he has one in his own country home in the Piemonte region of Italy). “The difference in working with this material versus, say, marble is that you’re not chipping away to see what emerges — you’re building from nothing,” he says. To Guadagnino, the “brash, glossy” rainbow surfaces suggest a dancing flame, though the fireplace is built to withstand real heat. “There may be a little crackling to the finish,” he says, “but I think that’s beautiful. It’s part of the story.” Studio Luca Guadagnino fireplace, price on request, info@studiolucaguadagnino.com.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Candles that Capture a Day at the Beach, Down to the Hot Dogs
description: Plus: vodkas made from oats and coffee cherry pulp, a retreat in the Cotswolds and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘El Gran Movimiento’ Review: Subsistence and the City
description: This cryptic Bolivian feature looks at metropolitan life through a defamiliarizing lens.
content: In the first shot of “El Gran Movimiento,” the second feature from the Bolivian director Kiro Russo, who also wrote the script, the camera zooms in from high above La Paz toward a half-standing building. As the image gets closer to ground level, the sounds below — traffic, construction, possibly voices — grow louder. Throughout the opening montage, Russo peers at the city through a defamiliarizing lens, surveying the buzzing wires of the aerial cable cars or pondering the reflections of vehicles and people in glass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Rogue Agent’ Review: The Spy Who Duped Me
description: James Norton stars as a British charmer who claims he’s an MI5 agent in this irksome thriller based on a true story.
content: Forget the Tinder swindler — how about the MI5 mountebank? Sounds chilling. Yet “Rogue Agent,” a stale thriller loosely based on actual events, suggests a different nightmare scenario: that on the heels of every true-crime documentary is a narrative adaptation zapping the story of substance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: ‘Everybody Is Armed’: As Shootings Soar, Philadelphia Is Awash in Guns
description: More than 1,400 people have been shot this year in Philadelphia, hundreds of them fatally — a higher toll than in much larger New York or Los Angeles.
content: PHILADELPHIA — The 300th killing of the year in Philadelphia took the life of Lameer Boyd, an 18-year-old father-to-be who was gunned down one July night on a sidewalk. Over the weeks that followed, a grandmother was shot in the neck, a popular singer was killed in front of his house and a woman was killed at a front-porch cookout.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Decisive Vote
description: Now that Joe Manchin has saved the Democratic agenda, how should liberals think about him?
content: Joe Manchin has spent much of the past year as the villain of liberal America, receiving the kind of criticism that’s usually reserved for Donald Trump, Mitch McConnell or a conservative Supreme Court justice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Finally, Some Good News on Inflation
description: What July’s Big Zero does — and doesn’t — mean for the future.
content: This is not the end of inflation. It is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, the end of the beginning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu and Nate Schweber
title: Boy, 14, Killed in New York City’s Second Teen Gun Death in Two Weeks
description: The 14-year-old boy was found in the lobby of an apartment complex in the Bronx, and the death is being investigated as potentially accidental, the police said.
content: A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot in the Bronx early Thursday, police officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Here are the main takeaways from Garland’s statement on the Mar-a-Lago search.
description: The fact that Attorney General Merrick B. Garland felt compelled to speak at all says much about the high stakes and the possible pitfalls of the investigation.
content: All week, former President Donald J. Trump’s allies pressed Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to explain the basis for the search warrant federal agents had executed at Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago residence — and he refused to break the silence he wears like his unwrinkled, federal blue suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur, John Liu and Amy Chang Chien
title: As China Vows More Military Exercises, Taiwan Is Undeterred
description: China’s drills have hardened Taiwan’s understated approach to navigating a big-power rivalry over its political future.
content: If China’s show of force over Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s trip was meant as a deterrent, it has not had the intended effect in Taiwan, where the military drills have reinforced a careful two-pronged strategy of shoring up international support, while avoiding overt confrontation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Driverless Cars Shouldn’t Be a Race
description: Sometimes it’s better to be safe than first.
content: I grind my teeth when the metaphor of “a race” is used in discussions about self-driving vehicle technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Mann
title: How to Watch the Perseid Meteor Shower Peak, if the Moon Isn’t in the Way
description: Fireballs may light up the sky for those willing to stay up late and take in the show.
content: Thursday night into Friday morning will be one of the special dates scattered throughout each year when skywatchers can catch a meteor shower as a multitude of flares potentially burst in the darkness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Josh Hawley’s Manhood, Mike Pompeo’s Midriff and Other 2024 Indicators
description: If Trump is inevitable, nobody told these Republican strivers.
content: Josh Hawley has a book about manhood coming out next year. Nikki Haley has a book about womanhood coming out in two months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Trump Hires #BillionDollarLawyer
description: As top allies of Donald J. Trump are called to testify in Atlanta, he has hired a high-profile local attorney best known for representing rappers.
content: ATLANTA — Amid a deepening swirl of federal and state investigations, former President Donald J. Trump has hired a prominent Atlanta lawyer to represent him in a criminal inquiry into election interference in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Wildfires Rip Through France, Again, Weeks After Last Heat Wave
description: In the southwest, a blaze that started in July has reignited because of the heat and the dry air, scorching an additional 26 square miles of bushes and forest.
content: PARIS — France is burning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Rishi Sunak Has a Sterling Résumé. It’s Not Helping Him Replace Boris Johnson.
description: Mr. Sunak is viewed by many in his party as too distant from ordinary Britons, and is being blamed by some for setting off the rebellion that toppled Prime Minister Boris Johnson.
content: CARDIFF, Wales — Just a few weeks ago Rishi Sunak, the former chancellor of the Exchequer, seemed well-placed to become Britain’s next prime minister, topping the short list of two contenders selected by Conservative Party lawmakers to replace the departing Boris Johnson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Will California Restrict Solitary Confinement?
description: State legislators are weighing a bill that would greatly limit which prisoners can be confined and for how long.
content: California legislators are weighing a major change to the state’s criminal justice system: banning long-term solitary confinement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Serena Williams Begins the Not-Too-Long Goodbye
description: Williams, who expects to retire after the U.S. Open, played what was likely her last match in Canada on Wednesday. It ended with a loss, and tears.
content: As a champion who says she hates goodbyes, Serena Williams could have made her exit from tennis in other ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Did the F.B.I. Just Re-Elect Donald Trump?
description: The coming clash between the legal system and the electoral system.
content: Why is Donald Trump so powerful? How did he come to dominate one of the two major parties and get himself elected president? Is it his hair? His waistline? No, it’s his narratives. Trump tells powerful stories that ring true to tens of millions of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Samples of Popular Diabetes Drug Contain Potential Carcinogen, F.D.A. Says
description: Testing found nitrosamine contamination in some samples of Januvia, but regulators will allow Merck to continue selling the drug for now.
content: The Food and Drug Administration said that traces of a potential carcinogen had been found in samples of a popular diabetes drug produced by Merck, the latest instance in which impurities were detected in top-selling pharmaceutical products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Heavy Losses Leave Russia Short of Its Goal, U.S. Officials Say
description: The estimated deaths and injuries are stalling Russia’s progress in eastern Ukraine, military experts say, as fighting intensifies in the south.
content: WASHINGTON — The staggeringly high rate of Russian casualties in Ukraine means that President Vladimir V. Putin may not be able to achieve one of his key war objectives: seizing the entire eastern region of the country this year, officials in the Biden administration and military experts say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: ‘We Are Living Things’ Review: The Truth Is Out There
description: Two undocumented immigrants from opposite sides of the world connect in Brooklyn — and over their shared trauma relating to apparent alien abductions.
content: Do you want to believe? Solomon (Jorge Antonio Guerrero) does — he already believes that his own mother was abducted by space aliens — which is probably easier than accepting what may be her truer and grizzlier fate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Rivian Reports $1.7 Billion Quarterly Loss as Supply Chain Problems Persist
description: The maker of electric pickup trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles affirmed its production forecast for the year.
content: Rivian, a fledgling electric-vehicle manufacturer, said Thursday that it lost $1.7 billion in the second quarter.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on What to Do With West Virginia
description: Co-workers disagree on which region the state belongs to.
content: Brian writes: My co-workers and I had a contest in which we divided the United States into 5 regions, and then voted on whose maps were best. I placed West Virginia in the Northeast, which was widely ridiculed. But West Virginia was created during the Civil War by Virginians opposed to the Confederacy. Please order my colleagues to respect the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Don’t Blame Monkeys for Monkeypox, W.H.O. Says After Attacks
description: The outbreak is centered on humans, not animals, health officials said, after a report that some monkeys were harmed in São Paulo, Brazil, out of fear of transmission, according to local authorities.
content: Monkeys are not to blame for the monkeypox outbreak that has triggered health alerts, including a national health emergency in the United States, as the viral disease has continued to spread, the World Health Organization said this week after reports of attacks against the animals in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Judge John Hodgman on What to Do With West Virginia
description: Co-workers disagree on which region the state belongs to.
content: Brian writes: My co-workers and I had a contest in which we divided the United States into 5 regions, and then voted on whose maps were best. I placed West Virginia in the Northeast, which was widely ridiculed. But West Virginia was created during the Civil War by Virginians opposed to the Confederacy. Please order my colleagues to respect the state’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By April Rubin
title: Don’t Blame Monkeys for Monkeypox, W.H.O. Says After Attacks
description: The outbreak is centered on humans, not animals, health officials said, after a report that some monkeys were harmed in São Paulo, Brazil, out of fear of transmission, according to local authorities.
content: Monkeys are not to blame for the monkeypox outbreak that has triggered health alerts, including a national health emergency in the United States, as the viral disease has continued to spread, the World Health Organization said this week after reports of attacks against the animals in Brazil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Says Its Covid Outbreak Is Over
description: Kim Jong-un declared “victory” over the virus, despite a lack of vaccines. Outside experts have cast doubt on the North’s pandemic-related claims.
content: SEOUL — North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, said the country had brought its coronavirus outbreak to an end without vaccines, state media reported on Thursday, while Mr. Kim’s sister accused South Korea of sending the virus across the border and threatened​ “deadly”​ retaliation​.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Kamoya Kimeu, Fossil-Hunting ‘Legend’ in East Africa, Is Dead
description: Working closely with the Leakey family in Kenya, he discovered many of the bones that rewrote how we understand human evolution.
content: Kamoya Kimeu, the son of a goat herder whose preternatural gift for spotting and identifying petrified tibias, skull fragments and other ancient human remains among the arid, rocky badlands of East Africa won him acclaim as the world’s greatest fossil hunter, died on July 20 in Nairobi, Kenya. He did not know his exact age, but believed it to be about 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: The Unfiltered Faces of Monkeypox
description: Men and women with monkeypox share their stories on social media, to fight stigma and demand more action.
content: When Matt Ford, 30, an actor in Los Angeles, tested positive for monkeypox in June, he posted videos on Twitter and TikTok to show what it was like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood and Billy Hickey
title: When Fireflies Await a Night That Never Comes
description: A study found that while some fireflies shrugged off light pollution, members of other species failed to mate even when males and females could find each other.
content: As dusk deepens the shadow at the forest’s edge, a tiny beacon lights up the gloom. Soon, the twilight is full of drifting lights, each winking a message in peculiar semaphore: “Male seeks female for brief union.” This courtship plays out on summer nights the world over among beetles of the Lampyridae family, commonly known as fireflies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: Rhythm of War: A Thunderous Blast, and Then a Coffee Break
description: This is a war fought in a cycle of opposites: bursts of chaos from outgoing and incoming shelling, and then long lulls in which soldiers undertake the most routine activities.
content: BAKHMUT, Ukraine — Ukrainian soldiers scurried around the howitzer in a field one recent morning. In a flurry of activity, one man lugged a 106-pound explosive shell from a truck to the gun. Another, using a wooden pole, shoved it into the breach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Cardinals Minor Leaguer Hits a Cycle of Home Runs
description: Chandler Redmond became just the second professional player to collect home runs of every variety in one game: solo, two-run, three-run and grand slam.
content: The concept of a cycle is familiar to most fans, even if the event is not particularly common: A player collects a single, double, triple and homer in the same game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: How New York City Lost 63 Miles of Pedestrian-Friendly ‘Open Streets’
description: The program, which was made permanent last year, gave New Yorkers more public spaces, but is retreating in many areas. Community advocates hope to stop that slide.
content: When city life was throttled by the pandemic, cars were removed from five blocks of 31st Avenue in Astoria, Queens, to make way for fresh-air strolling and socializing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Could Carl Paladino and His ‘3-Ring Circus’ Be Headed for Congress?
description: Mr. Paladino, who has a history of racist and outrageous remarks, is competing in a Republican House primary against the G.O.P. state chairman.
content: OLEAN, N.Y. — During his decade-plus in New York politics, Carl Paladino has had no problem making headlines, usually for all the wrong reasons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘Emergency Declaration’ Review: Midair Contagion
description: The “Parasite” star Song Kang-ho plays a detective working to thwart a plan to unleash a deadly virus on unsuspecting plane passengers.
content: It’s not enough for a disaster movie to rely on spectacle and peril; the crisis must allow characters to transcend their baser instincts so they might inspire hope. “Emergency Declaration,” a piercing thriller from the South Korean writer-director Han Jae-rim, manages to deliver excitement and melodrama out of a ludicrous story line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Silver-Haired and Shameless About Perks: Retirees Take Part-Time Work in the Travel Industry
description: Spend 15 hours a week loading baggage at the airport or passing out towels at the pool, and you can see Europe for a fraction of the usual cost.
content: Maria Boyd-Scott turned 60 last month, and she and her wife, Joey Boyd-Scott, 68, celebrated the milestone in style: They flew business class to Amsterdam, staying at a Hilton for two nights, and then headed to France for two nights at the Waldorf Astoria Versailles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: The Jan. 6 attack was a crisis. So why wasn’t it more of a scandal?
description: The political dog that didn’t bark.
content: Never underestimate the power of a political scandal. I don’t mean in the gossipy, prurient, sense of the term, like a splashy story about celebrity cheating on a spouse. Rather, I’m talking about an event that provokes such outrage that it can unite previously divided populations and politicians in condemnation. That kind of scandal can change history, opening up paths to political change that may have seemed unimaginable up to that point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsea Garrison, Paige Cowett, Lisa Chow, Anita Badejo, Ben Calhoun, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Chris Wood and Corey Schreppel
title: Pregnant at 16
description: How the experiences of two women led them to opposite sides of the abortion fight.
content: This episode contains strong language and descriptions of an abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Mack & Rita’ Review: 70 Is the New 30
description: An influencer emerges from a tanning bed 40 years older in this playful movie starring Diane Keaton.
content: In the Diane Keaton comedy “Mack & Rita,” the 30-year-old Mack (Elizabeth Lail) has always felt like an old soul. Recently, tuckered out by the demands of being a social-media influencer and hurt by not making headway on her second novel, she just wants a rest. At her bestie Carla’s bachelorette jaunt to Palm Springs, Calif., Mack repairs to a retrofitted tanning bed advertised by a seeming charlatan named Luka (Simon Rex) as a life-regression pod.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Gopnik
title: Seeing Double? So Do Great Artists.
description: At the National Gallery in Washington, D.C., a thrilling new show, “The Double,” proves the surprising power of duplication.
content: At the very start of “The Double: Identity and Difference in Art Since 1900,” a brilliant new show at the National Gallery, stands an 8-foot-tall plywood column, painted plain gray without ornament. Standing by itself, it would come across as simply architectonic. But it isn’t alone: An identical column lies on the ground alongside, and the pairing — now inevitably understood as one standing figure and another, recumbent — comes to represent the basic sociability of all humans. The twinned figures in this 1961 piece by Robert Morris, “Two Columns,” can stand for all of humanity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Adam Goldman
title: Man suspected of trying to breach the F.B.I.’s Cincinnati office may have Jan. 6 ties.
description: Investigators are looking into whether the man who tried to breach the F.B.I.’s field office in Cincinnati on Thursday had ties to extremist groups, including one that participated in the Jan. 6 attack.
content: Investigators are looking into whether the man who tried to breach the F.B.I.’s field office in Cincinnati on Thursday had ties to extremist groups, including one that participated in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, according to two law enforcement officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Greenhouse
title: Alito’s Call to Arms to Secure Religious Liberty
description: The challenge, he says, is to convince people who are not religious that religion is  worth special protection.
content: Barely a month after handing down the majority opinion that erased the right to abortion, Justice Samuel Alito traveled to Rome to give a keynote address at a “religious liberty summit” convened by the Religious Liberty Initiative of the University of Notre Dame’s law school. As the video that Notre Dame posted of the bearded justice delivering his remarks made clear, this was a victory lap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Final Bid
description: David W. Tuffs’s puzzle is positively “Babelesque.”
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — In English, wordplay lovers can find a number of things to keep them entertained, but even then, there is always more to discover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Did the Pandemic Deepen Relationships in Your Life? We Want To Hear About It.
description: Tell us about relationships that started during the pandemic and ones that have evolved or been shaped by the last few years.
content: The pandemic forced many of us into spending unexpected, extended periods of time with unfamiliar neighbors, family members or strangers. Many of these connections progressed into deep friendships and other kinds of bonds, and have continued to grow and evolve as society has reopened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Summering’ Review: The Besties Confront Bittersweet Truths
description: This meditative coming-of-age movie by James Ponsoldt tracks the emotional upheavals of four 11-year-old girls who stumble upon a corpse.
content: In “Summering,” a meditative coming-of-age film by James Ponsoldt (“The Spectacular Now”), four 11-year-old girls living in suburban Utah are suddenly confronted with the realities of the adult world in the last days of summer vacation before they begin middle school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Roger E. Mosley, Actor Best Known for ‘Magnum, P.I.,’ Dies at 83
description: He played Leadbelly and Sonny Liston on the big screen. But his most high-profile role was a rugged, wry Vietnam War veteran opposite Tom Selleck on TV.
content: Roger E. Mosley, whose knack for playing a tough guy with a mischievous streak earned him accolades playing an action-ready helicopter pilot on the hit 1980s television series “Magnum, P.I.,” as well as real-life figures like Sonny Liston and Leadbelly on the big screen, died on Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Read the full transcript of Merrick Garland’s comments on the F.B.I.’s search of Trump’s home.
description: Here is what the attorney general said on Thursday about the process that led up to the action at Mar-a-Lago.
content: Good afternoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farhad Manjoo
title: Alex Jones and the Wellness-Conspiracy Industrial Complex
description: The Sandy Hook defamation trial showed how bogus health products have turned misinformation into big business.
content: When Owen Shroyer, an anchor and reporter for Infowars, took the stand late last month in the defamation trial of his boss, the far-right conspiracy theorist Alex Jones, he was asked about the many health products for sale on Jones’s site. Among them: diet pills, fluoride-free toothpaste that Jones once claimed “kills the whole SARS-corona family at point-blank range” and InstaHard, a supplement whose purpose I probably don’t have to spell out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: Garland Moves to Release Details on Search of Trump’s Home
description: The search was part of a government effort to account for materials related to some of the most highly classified programs run by the United States, a person briefed on the matter said.
content: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland moved on Thursday to make public the legal authorization for the F.B.I.’s search of former President Donald J. Trump’s home in Florida, which was carried out as part of the government’s effort to account for documents that one person briefed on the matter said related to some of the most highly classified programs run by the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Peter Beagle, Author of ‘The Last Unicorn,’ Is Back In Control
description: After losing control of his intellectual property — including the book, a classic and a strong seller for decades — he has regained the rights, and is publishing again.
content: Peter Beagle started writing “The Last Unicorn” in a cabin in Cheshire, Mass. when he was 22 years old. Published in 1968, the book remains a strong seller, a classic in the fantasy genre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Arctic Warming Is Happening Faster Than Described, Analysis Shows
description: The warming at the top of the globe, a sign of climate change, is happening much faster than previously described compared with the global average, scientists said Thursday.
content: The rapid warming of the Arctic, a definitive sign of climate change, is occurring even faster than previously described, researchers in Finland said Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Progressives Push Democrats to Make Their Fight About Freedom, Too
description: Democrats at every level of the party are increasingly seeking to reclaim language about freedom and personal liberty from Republicans, as part of their midterms messaging.
content: For much of the midterm campaign, Democrats have grappled with how to define their message, weighing slogans like “Democrats deliver” and “Build back better,” and issuing warnings against “ultra-MAGA” Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Shannon Bream to Replace Chris Wallace as ‘Fox News Sunday’ Host
description: She will be the first woman to hold the role in the program’s 26-year history.
content: Fox News has selected its chief legal correspondent and late-night news anchor, Shannon Bream, to be the host of its signature political talk show, “Fox News Sunday,” elevating a woman to the role for the first time in the program’s 26-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: What Are Burn Pits, and How Did They Harm U.S. Troops?
description: Veterans and their advocates describe continuously burning fires on overseas bases that consumed the military’s trash and produced toxic smoke.
content: On bases established for America’s post-9/11 wars, the U.S. military’s trash was often burned in huge, open-air lots on the perimeters of the overseas outposts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Howorth
title: American Literature Loses Out to Consolidation
description: The proposed merger of Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster accelerates industry trends toward the production of best sellers at the expense of the incubation of new voices or ideas.
content: OXFORD, Miss. — Penguin Random House, the largest English-language trade book publisher in the world, has made an offer to acquire Simon & Schuster, another large publisher and one of its rivals. For American consumers, this is bad news. Allison Hill, the chief executive of the American Booksellers Association, a trade association that promotes independent bookstores like mine, said the sale “threatens to undermine competition … and put bookstores and authors at risk.” A lawyer for the Justice Department, which is suing to block the purchase, commented that the lawsuit “will prevent further consolidation in an industry that has a history of collusion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: A Moscow court places a former state television journalist under house arrest over her anti-war protest.
description: A former Russian state television journalist who gained global attention for staging a rare protest against the war in Ukraine live on air has been placed under house arrest on criminal charges by a Moscow court over a recent demonstration against President Vladimir V. Putin, her lawyer said Thursday.
content: A former Russian state television journalist who gained global attention for staging a rare protest against the war in Ukraine live on air has been placed under house arrest on criminal charges by a Moscow court over a recent demonstration against President Vladimir V. Putin, her lawyer said Thursday.
